name: NPR
text:
As a "social circus," Zip Zap aims to foster personal development and positive social change. It's become world-famous along the way — entertaining everyone from Roger Federer to Obama.

"Respect — that's what I've learnt from Zip Zap," says one performer.
https://t.co/wdEzoSfywt

name: NPR
text: With Biden leading in the polls, Democrats are haunted by the ghosts of 2016 when Hillary Clinton led, too. But there are a few key factors that make this year's election different, writes @DomenicoNPR. https://t.co/vJHxyxWuBB

name: NPR
text:
The title of Nate Marshall's new book comes from the phrase "fixing to." It's "all about what happens next. It's this thing that is informed by history, but that is all about looking forward, all about possibility."

"That's sort of what I hope poems do." https://t.co/v7SOYCaiK7

name: NPR
text: Nebraska expects to have only about $50 million less to spend than projected before the pandemic, nowhere near the kind of dropoff seen in other states. @NETNewsNebraska https://t.co/L9zstNOgLT

name: NPR
text: West Virginia's governor has faced criticism for how he decided to use some of his state's $1.25 billion from the federal CARES Act, meant for states to cover coronavirus-related expenses. @wvpublic https://t.co/NjNaIPXkCA

name: NPR
text:
Farms have already reported coronavirus outbreaks among hundreds of workers. 

And yet, the federal government hasn't established any enforceable rules to protect farmworkers from the virus or instruct farms what to do when they get sick. 
https://t.co/Zzv7JJ7iUk

name: NPR
text: New York and Connecticut are launching investigations into utility companies as millions remain without power a day after Tropical Storm Isaias tore through the Northeast. https://t.co/NTmV4MMxOq

name: NPR
text:
Tim Minchin's friend came up with the premise for his new series, "Upright." 

"He wanted to create a comedy show with me in it that involved a guy trying to get across Australia with a piano on the back of a ute," he says. 
https://t.co/tJVhHhhHap

name: NPR
text: Since many of us know Bryan Cranston from Breaking Bad, @waitwait invited him to play a game called "Braking ... good!" — 3 questions about safe driving. https://t.co/v1zBplRIqf

name: NPR
text:
New York's 14-day quarantine requirement for travelers from high-risk states is legally binding. But authorities can't force people to register for follow-up — leaving it largely dependent on goodwill and voluntary compliance.
https://t.co/kkizWeC21T

name: NPR
text:
An author explores her sister's death under mysterious circumstances in a hotel in Mexico — offering more plot twists, shocking revelations and shady characters than most contemporary thrillers, our reviewer says.
https://t.co/halpFnsldu

name: NPR
text:
For more than a century, food has been getting more abundant — and cheaper. And yet people keep worrying about shortages. 

Some economists say the fears actually create their own problems.
https://t.co/CnjADWZWbS

name: NPR
text: Duval County has been a reliable Republican vote for over four decades. But Democrats are sensing new optimism ahead of the election, thanks to intense anti-Trump energy among black voters, young voters and college-educated professionals in the suburbs. https://t.co/U9QhbwOIJC

name: NPR
text: It's difficult to eradicate a virus completely, and COVID-19 isn't any different. The disease might never go away, but it doesn't mean that everyone will have to self-isolate forever. https://t.co/fnRagqJtq3

name: NPR
text: With theaters and movies on hold during the pandemic, it can feel like there's not much else to do but binge on TV. We ask reporters in eight countries to tell us what TV shows people have been obsessed about. https://t.co/Whdz5bIx2M
